pr_title: testUnmanagedThreadSubmitsTask waits for what never happens

timeline.message: Issue #10347 testUnmanagedThreadSubmitsTask waits for what never happens

timeline.bodyText: Instead of adding this logic inline, why not correct the logic in pollForResult?
timeline.author: gjwatts

replies.bodyText: Because pollForResult was interpreted to mean different things to different tests that used it.  Its behavior was only incorrect if you are looking at one of the tests that didn't want it to behave the way it did, otherwise it was doing exactly the right thing, and altering it would break that.  It's a good example of why this sort of utility method is a bad practice in tests.  Developers writing a test think they know what it does based on its name and start to unknowingly misuse it.  The solution here is to remove it and let each test perform precisely the steps that it needs inline, which will be ideal for future debugging as well as for ensuring correctness.

timeline.bodyText: Is statusB.isDone() the same thing as statusB.hasResult()?
timeline.author: gjwatts

replies.bodyText: They are similar, but not the same.  For repeating tasks (which doesn't apply here) a task can have multiple results - one for each execution.  The hasResult method tells you if at least one execution of the task has happened, such that you can get a current result.  The isDone method tells you that all executions have completed.  For one-time tasks, such as is the case here, they are both telling you the same thing.
